title: Greg Abbott
deleted: Following the widespread power outages caused by the [[February 13–16, 2021 North American winter storm]], Abbott stated the situation at the [[Electric Reliability Council of Texas]] (ERCOT) was "unacceptable" and that he would be prioritizing reform to ERCOT.<ref>{{cite web |title='Massive failure': Why are millions of people in Texas still without power? |url=https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/nation/2021/02/16/texas-weather-power-outage-rolling-blackouts-leave-millions-dark/6764764002/ |website=www.usatoday.com |access-date=18 February 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

title: Greg Abbott
deleted: An article in the ''[[The Washington Post]]'' said that the power outages were not caused by an "engineering problem" but from a "free market" problem. The electric grid in Texas emphasizes "cheap prices over reliable service".<ref name="WaPo_Englund_20210216"/> In Houston—the fourth most populated city in the US—the wholesale price of electricity increased from US$22 a megawatt-hour to about US$9,000.<ref name="WaPo_Englund_20210216"/>

title: Greg Abbott
added: Abbott is running for a third term.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Tilove|first=Jonathan|date=June 14, 2019|title=Tilove: Abbott says Biden will fade and Trump will win Texas|url=https://www.statesman.com/news/20190614/tilove-abbott-says-biden-will-fade-and-trump-will-win-texas|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=February 25, 2021|website=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|quote=He said he plans to run for a third term in 2022.}}</ref>
